questions.text: A victim was recovered from the site of a terrorist attack. Which of the following conclusions can be made from the image shown below of the victim?

choices.text: The victim has been shot at with a shotgun from close range.
The victim has been hit by multiple shrapnel, possibly from an explosion.
The victim has had multiple cut wounds all over the body.
The victim has had multiple stab wounds all over the body.

questions.solution:
From the image shown, it can be inferred that the victim has been hit by multiple shrapnel, possibly from an explosion. Shrapnel wounds are also called secondary blast injuries. 

Blast injury is a complex type of physical trauma, resulting from direct or indirect exposure to an explosion that causes a sudden increase or decrease in atmospheric pressure.

TK Marshall (Marshall's triad) described the characteristic injuries associated with bomb explosions:

  • Abrasions
  • Bruises/contusions
  • Puncture lacerations
Blast injuries are classified as follows:
  • Primary injuries: These are caused by the effect of transmitted blast waves on gas-containing structures and are characterized by only internal injuries. 
  • Secondary injuries: These are injuries caused by shrapnel and other airborne debris propelled by the explosion. These injuries may affect any part of the body and sometimes result in penetrating trauma. Most casualties are caused by secondary injuries.
  • Tertiary injuries: These are caused by blast wind that can throw victims against solid objects.
  • Quaternary injuries: All other injuries caused by explosions that are not included in the above three categories, e.g. flash burns, crush injuries, respiratory effects due to toxic dust, and gas

Other options:

The highly spread-out nature of the wounds effectively rules out close-range shotgun injury. Also, the pattern of the wounds is not consistent with cuts or stabs.

questions.text: An elderly woman with strangulated femoral hernia has abdominal pain and fecal vomits. Small intestines were found to be perforated. The next day she underwent a release of hernia and resection of intestines with an end- to-end anastomosis. After that, she started developing signs of peritonitis and died 3 days later. Which of the following options is the most appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate?
questions.solution:
Peritonitis is appropriate for line I (a) of the death certificate as it is the disease/condition directly leading to death.

In this patient:

  • I(a) - Disease directly leading to death: Peritonitis
  • I(b) - Antecedent cause: Perforation of small intestine
  • I(c) - Condition which gave rise to the antecedent cause: Strangulated femoral hernia

Terminal events like circulatory failure and respiratory failure, are modes of dying. They should not be written as the immediate cause of death in the death certificate because they are only signs of death and provide no useful information regarding the underlying disease process.

Refer the last line in the death certificate with an asterisk (*).

questions.text: The ‘en bloc' removal of organs is a feature of which of the following autopsy techniques?
questions.solution:
The 'en bloc' removal of organs is done in the Ghon technique. In this procedure, the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and urogenital organs are removed as organ blocks.

The 'en masse' removal of organs is done in the Letulle technique. It is the removal of the cervical, thoracic, abdominal, and pelvic organs as a single organ mass. The mass is then dissected into organ blocks.

Related Pearl: Autopsy Techniques

  • Virchow's technique: Organs are removed one by one from the body to be examined. Here the cranial cavity is opened first, then the spinal cord, followed by thoracic, cervical, and abdominal organs in that order.
  • Ghon's technique: Here the organs are removed 'en bloc'. The thoracic, cervical, pelvic, and abdominal organs are removed as organ blocks.
  • Rokitansky's technique: This is characterized by 'in situ' dissection in part combined with en bloc removal like Ghon's technique. The dissection begins at the neck and slowly works its way down the body and the organ is removed as a bloc. A cut is first made at the larynx to separate the esophagus from the pharynx. The larynx and trachea are pulled downward and using a scalpel, the chest organs are cut. The diaphragm is cut to expose the abdominal organs. Other organs like the bladder and rectum are separated from the body by using a scalpel to cut the pelvic ligaments.
  • Letulle's technique: Thoracic, cervical, abdominal, and pelvic organs are removed 'en masse' meaning as one big organ block. It allows the body to be made available for examination in less than 30 minutes as the process of removing the organs is much quicker.

questions.text: A woman gave birth to twin babies of gestational ages differing by a few weeks. On detailed evaluation, it was noted that the disparity in gestational age of babies was due to fertilization of 2 different ova released in 2 different menstrual cycles. What is this phenomenon known as?
questions.solution:
The above phenomenon is known as superfetation. It occurs when there is fertilization of 2 different ova released in different menstrual cycles. The consequence is two children are born at the same time and one of them might be mature while another might be immature.

Ovulation usually stops with the onset of pregnancy, but in a few individuals, ovulation may be possible till the first trimester, after which the decidual cavity is obliterated. The fertilization of the newly released ovum in a woman who is already pregnant may take place following coitus. 

Other options:

Option A: Superfecundation is the fertilization of 2 different ova in the same menstrual cycle by separate acts of coitus. Heteropaternal superfecundation is used to refer to instances of two different males fathering fraternal twins. This leads to the possibility of twins also being half-siblings. This may raise doubts regarding adultery and infidelity. 

Option C: A supposititious child is also known as a fictitious child. In such cases, a woman pretends to be pregnant and substitutes a living child as her own, or may substitute a male child for her female child, or abortion. This is done to claim property. This can be identified by verifying the signs of pregnancy and delivery in the woman and by DNA fingerprinting.

Option D: Atavism is the reappearance of a characteristic in an individual after several generations of absence. For example, the child may not resemble his parents but resembles his grandparents. This is attributed to the recombination of genes.

questions.text: A young boy presents to the emergency department after being at a party. He says he tasted a small colorful graphic blotting paper while at the party. Within minutes, he had started to feel his heart race, had profuse sweating and tremors, and was rushed to the hospital. Later, he develops extreme paranoia and extreme panic and starts crying. Examination of the eyes shows mydriasis. Which of the following drugs did he most likely consume?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of lysergic acid diethylamide (LSD) abuse. The patient developed extreme panic and paranoia after tasting a small colorful blotting paper, which is suggestive of a bad trip. Other features that support this diagnosis are palpitation, profuse sweating, tremors, and pupillary dilation.

LSD is the most powerful hallucinogen known to man. Increased sympathetic activity like tachycardia, hypertension, pupillary dilation, tremor, and fever can be seen within minutes of oral intake. Apart from this, the users may have psychiatric symptoms like visual illusions, extreme changes in mood, paranoid delusions, etc. Patients may experience bad trips, where they have panic episodes. Prolonged experience without further exposure to drugs known as “flashbacks" can also result from LSD use. 

Stopping the drug abruptly after continued use does not produce withdrawal symptoms. Management of bad trips due to LSD abuse involves supportive treatment with anxiolytics.

Other named effects of drug use:

  • Amotivational syndrome - Chronic use of cannabis may lead to amotivational syndrome with lethargy and lack of interest in day-to-day activities.
  • Run amok - This is a psychic disturbance resulting from continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania.
  • Magnan syndrome - This is a type of tactile hallucination seen in chronic users of cocaine where they feel as if grains of sand are under the skin or insects are creeping on the skin (formication)

Other options:

Option A: Cannabis intoxication causes feelings of detachment, euphoria, relaxation, decreased concentration, and attention span. Images appear vivid. There is increased thirst and appetite.

Option B: Amphetamine intoxication also gives rise to similar clinical features like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, tremors, dilated pupils, and paranoia. However, the ingestion of blotting paper, makes LSD more likely.

Option D: Cocaine intoxication may also have similar features, like tachycardia, hypertension, sweating, dilated pupils, and altered behavior. It also causes anesthesia in the area that has been in direct contact with the drug. Magnan syndrome may also be seen.

questions.text:
Match the following:
  1. Punishable as per Section 290 IPC
  2. Punishable as per Section 376 IPC
  3. Punishable as per Section 297 IPC
  1. In an empty factory, a man has forceful penetrative intercourse with a woman he kidnapped
  2. In a crowded railway station, an individual obtains sexual gratification when he rubs his private parts against a woman's back
  3. In a lonely graveyard, a person is caught performing a sexual act with a corpse
questions.solution:
The correct answer is 1-B, 2-A, 3-C

  • Case A is an example of rape, which is punishable under section 376 of the IPC. The definition of rape is under section 375 of the IPC and is as follows- A man is said to commit rape if he has sexual intercourse with a woman under circumstances falling under any of the six following descriptions:
    • First– Against her will.
    • Second – Without her consent.
    • Third – With her consent, when her consent has been obtained by putting her or any person in whom she is interested in fear of death or of hurt.
    • Fourth – With her consent, when the man knows that he is not her husband and that her consent is given because she believes that he is another man to whom she is or believes herself to be lawfully married.
    • Fifth – With her consent, when, at the time of giving such consent, by reason of unsoundness of mind or intoxication or the administration by him personally or through another of any stupefying or unwholesome substance, she is unable to understand the nature and consequences of that to which she gives consent.
    • Sixth – With or without her consent, when she is under eighteen years of age.
  • Case B is an example of Frotteurism. It refers to the act of obtaining sexual gratification by contact with another person (rubbing his private parts against female buttocks, breasts, thighs, etc. in crowds, etc). It is punishable under Sections 290 and 291 of the IPC, with a fine of up to Rs 200.
  • Case C is an example of Necrophilia. It refers to the desire for sexual intercourse with dead bodies. It is said to have a sadomasochistic foundation and that decomposition, foul smell, and coldness act as stimulants. Necrophagia is the extreme degree of sadism in which the person after mutilating the body, sucks or licks the wounds, bites the skin, drinks the blood, and eats the flesh of his victim to derive sexual pleasure. They are both punishable under section 297 of IPC, with a fine, up to 1-year imprisonment, or both.

questions.text: A woman presented with vomiting and diarrhea followed by chest pain and palpitations. Later, it was revealed that due to her unfaithfulness, her husband poisoned her with foxglove. Which of the following is the most specific treatment for this condition?
questions.solution:
Digitalis purpurea is also known as foxglove. The most specific antidote for its poisoning is digoxin-immune Fab fragments. 

Digitalis is a cardioactive steroid that acts by inhibiting the sodium/potassium (Na+-K+) ATPase pump. Acute toxicity closely resembles that caused by digoxin and includes early GI symptoms, followed by cardiac dysrhythmias.

Digoxin immune Fab fragments should be administered to those with serum potassium >5 mEq/L in patients with acute toxicity.

questions.text:
Which of the following scenarios would be considered as criminal negligence by a doctor?
  1. Operating on the wrong limb
  2. Failure to attend to the patient on time
  3. Failure to provide a substitute in his/her absence
  4. Mismanagement of delivery under influence of alcohol
  5. Failure to order an x-ray even when clearly indicated
questions.solution:
The scenarios that would be considered criminal negligence by the doctor include:

  • Operating on the wrong limb
  • Mismanagement of delivery under influence of alcohol

Failure to attend to the patient on time, failure to provide a substitute in his/her absence, and failure to order an x-ray even when clearly indicated contribute to civil negligence.

Professional negligence is defined as the absence of reasonable care and skill, or wilful negligence of a medical practitioner in the treatment of a patient, which causes bodily injury or death to the patient. It is of 4 types:

  1. Civil negligence
  2. Criminal negligence
  3. Corporate negligence
  4. Contributory negligence
Feature Civil negligence Criminal negligence
Offense No violation of law Violation of a criminal law
Type of negligence A simple absence of care and skill Gross inattention and lack of competency
Consent for act Good defense Not a good defense, can be prosecuted
Evidence Strong evidence is sufficient Guilt should be proved beyond reasonable doubt
Litigation Between 2 parties Between state and doctor
Punishment Liable to pay damages Imprisonment with or without fine

Related Pearl: Contributory negligence

Contributory negligence occurs when a patient or his personal attendant shows unreasonable conduct or absence of ordinary care, which when combined with the negligence of the doctor, has contributed to the injury. In this case, the patient’s or attendant’s negligence should be the direct, proximate cause and without which the injury would not have occurred.

So, contributory negligence occurs when both the doctor and patient are negligent. The direct or proximate cause of the injury should be the patient’s negligence, which means that if the patient was not negligent, the injury could have been prevented.

Contributory negligence usually occurs when the doctor is negligent and the patient:

  • Fails to give an accurate medical history, and as a result, the doctor may misdiagnose or mistreat the patient.
  • Fails to follow the doctor’s instructions
  • Refuses to take the treatment
  • Leaves the hospital against doctor’s advice
  • Does not inform the doctor or seek further medical assistance if the symptoms persist or worsens.

Contributory negligence is a defence for doctor’s negligence in civil cases. However, from case to case, the liability of a doctor may vary from complete non-liability to substantial liability for the damages. Under the doctrine of comparative negligence, the court has the right to hold both parties liable for their negligent actions.

Limitations / Exceptions to contributory negligence:

A. The doctor will be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. The doctor failed to provide proper instructions to the patient

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and did not tell the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (no proper instruction). The patient develops numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

 2. Last clear chance doctrine: It is applicable when the doctor fails to take necessary action to prevent damage due to a negligent act of the patient, even after getting a clear chance to take such action.

  • Ex: Doctor applies a tight plaster cast (doctor is negligent) to the patient’s leg and told the patient to inform if he develops any numbness (gave proper instruction). The patient developed numbness and has not informed the doctor (patient is negligent). Next day patient informed the doctor, but the doctor did not remove the cast and said he was busy (There was a clear last chance, but the doctor neglected again). After few days patient developed a permanent injury.

B. The doctor/person will not be held guilty in the following conditions:

1. Avoidable consequences rule: It occurs when an injury is caused due to doctor’s negligence, and the patient has done a negligent act, which further aggravated the injury caused by the doctor, and the patient could have avoided the consequence by not doing such act. In such cases, the doctor need not pay anything, and the patient will be held guilty.

  • Ex: A patient had a lacerated wound. The doctor examined the patient and had not done any dressing or provided any antibiotics (the doctor is negligent). However, the doctor instructed the patient to avoid contamination and asked him to visit the clinic next week. When the patient went home, he applied cow dung on his wound every day thinking that the wound would heal faster and didn't visit the doctor after one week. The wound got infected and developed pus and aggravated the injury.
  • Here, despite the doctor being negligent in the first instance, the patient is responsible for his injury as he performed an unnecessary, avoidable act, which aggravated the injury. The doctor need not pay anything.

2. Good Samaritan doctrine: A person who assists another person who is in serious danger cannot be charged with contributory negligence. unless such assistance is reckless or rash.

  • Ex: A person was travelling on a road and saw a car accident, where the victim was unconscious and was stuck inside the car. He called the ambulance. The paramedical staff instructed him not to mobilize the victim until they arrived. Meanwhile, the car was caught in fire (serious danger), and the person tried to remove the victim carefully out of the car (assisted the victim and was not reckless). However, the victim already had a cervical bone fracture due to the accident, which got mobilized while he was being removed out of the car and as a result, suffered an injury to the spine that led to paralysis (victim’s injury was aggravated). In such a case, the good samaritan doctrine would apply and the person who tried to help, will not be charged under contributory negligence.

questions.text: While performing an autopsy on a burn victim, the following cutaneous findings were noted. What is the term used to describe these burns?
questions.solution:
The term used to describe the burns shown in the image is filigree burn or arborescent burn or Lichtenberg’s flower or feathering. It is a finding in burns due to lightning.

The fern-like pattern of erythema in the skin indicates the path taken by the electrical discharge. It usually occurs over the shoulder or the flanks within an hour of the injury and disappears in a day or two. It occurs due to the rupture of small vessels and is seen in a fern-like pattern or the branching of a tree. 

Option B: When the skin is in firm contact with an electrical conductor, splitting of the layers of the epidermis or those of the epidermal-dermal junction. This may in turn produce a raised blister known as a Joule burn.

questions.text: A forensic expert receives the skull of a gunshot victim. What is the sequence of gunshots in this case?
questions.solution:
The sequence of gunshots, in this case, is 1→ 2→ 3 according to Puppe's rule.

Puppe's rule states that the path of a second fracture line does not cross the path of an existing fracture line that appears or was caused before it. This helps the forensic expert determine the chronology (order) in which the bullets were lodged into the skull. 

Puppe's rule is used in forensic examination of skull fractures caused by multiple blunt force vectors as well, as it is not limited to the examination of bullet injuries only.

questions.text: Which of the following features is not seen in mercury poisoning?
questions.solution:
Vineyard sprayer's lung is not a feature of mercury poisoning.

Vineyard sprayer's lung is seen as a result of chronic exposure to copper sulphate spray that is used as an insecticide in vineyards. The pathology consists of histiocytic granulomatous changes in the lung. 

Other options:

Option 1- Danbury tremors are a clinical manifestation seen in chronic exposure to elemental mercury. These tremors initially begin in the hands and then go on to involve the lips, tongue, arms, and legs. They are coarse tremors interrupted by jerky movements. 

Option 2- Erethism is commonly encountered in mirror manufacturing firm employees due to the physiological effects of mercury poisoning. Features include anxiety, depression, irritability, delusions and hallucinations, suicidal melancholia, etc.

Option 3- Pink disease or Acrodynia is the dermatological manifestation of mercury poisoning. Children are usually affected by this hypersensitivity reaction. It is characterized by sweating, skin rash, with hands and feet becoming puffy, pinkish, and painful. Associated paresthesia and skin peeling are also seen.

questions.text:
Arrange the following organs in the order of appearance of rigor mortis.

1 - Upper extremities
2 - Fingers
3 - Chest
4 - Legs
5 - Abdomen
questions.solution:
The correct sequence is 3-1-5-4-2. Chest -> Upper extremities-> Abdomen -> Legs -> Fingers.
The basic sequence of the rigor mortis begins from the head down the body, in order. It disappears in the same order of appearance.

Nysten's rule describes the sequential onset of rigor mortis in the various muscle groups. Rigor mortis (cadaveric rigidity or death stiffening) refers to the stiffening and shortening of muscles following death. It usually begins 1-2 hours after death and gets well established by 9-12 hours. The order of appearance of rigor mortis: Left chamber of the heart is affected first.

Other muscles are affected in the given order:

  1. Involuntary muscles: Heart
  2. Eyelids
  3. Neck and lower jaw
  4. Face
  5. Chest
  6. Upper extremities
  7. Abdomen
  8. Legs
  9. Fingers and toes

In individual limbs, it usually progresses from above downwards.

questions.text: You were posted for the forensic examination of victims of an airplane explosion, following an emergency landing.  You decide to use Gustafson's method for age estimation.  Which of the following statements is correct regarding the method?

choices.text: Root transparency is the most reliable criteria.
Age above twelve  years can be estimated.
Weight and length of the teeth are measured.
Nitrogen content of the enamel is  measured.

questions.solution:
According to Gustafson's method, root transparency is the most reliable criterion.

Gustafson's method of estimating the age of an individual is based on physiological changes in dental tissues. It is mainly useful in adults over 21 years of age (option B).

Gustafson’s criteria:

  • Attrition - Gradual wear and tear changes of the occlusal or upper surface due to mastication
  • Periodontosis -  Regression of gums and periodontal tissue surrounding the tooth, resulting in loosening of the tooth and falling
  • Secondary dentin - Deposition of dentin in the pulp cavity and gradual decrease in the size of the cavity
  • Cementum apposition - Cementum increases in thickness near the end of the root due to changes in the tooth position. Secondary cementum deposition occurs continually and slowly, forming incremental lines.
  • Root resorption -  Involves both cementum and dentin, which show characteristic sharp grooves 
  • Transparency of the root - This is the most reliable criteria. Canals in dentin get filled with minerals, and they become transparent gradually. Dentine becomes transparent due to rarefaction.

Other options:

Option C - Weight and height of the erupting teeth of a child are used to estimate the age of infants by Stack's method, not Gustafson's method.

Option D -  Chemical methods for estimation of the nitrogen content of enamel, which increases with age, are used for estimating the age beyond 25 years. It is not a part of Gustafson's criteria.

questions.text: Which of the following tests on live birth are based on the changes in the middle ear?
questions.solution:
Wredin’s test is based on the changes in the middle ear.

Tests for live birth:

  • Wredin’s test – Before birth, the middle ear does not contain air. It only contains gelatinous embryonic connective tissue. With respiration, the eustachian tube opens and the gelatinous substance is replaced by air. For this, the middle ear must be opened underwater by removing tegmen tympani. If an air bubble comes out, the test is said to be positive. This is not at all reliable.
  • Fodere’s test – Based on the increase in the weight of the lung due to increased blood flow after birth. The weight of unrespired lung is 30–40g whereas the weight of respired lung is 60–66 g.
  • Ploucquet’s test – Based on the ratio of the weight of the lung to the weight of the body in unrespired and respired lungs.
    • Unrespired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:70
    • Respired lungs: Weight of lungs: weight of body = 1:35
  • Breslau’s second life test: Air enters the stomach and intestine during respiration in a live-born fetus. So if respiration has taken place, they float in water, otherwise, they sink.

questions.text: You were posted for an autopsy of a 32-year-old man who was murdered by a serial killer. On examination, a fracture caused by a blow with a hammer was found in the skull as shown below. What is the type of fracture called?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario and image given above are suggestive of a depressed fracture.

A depressed fracture is caused by blows from a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. It is also called a signature fracture as the pattern of fracture resembles the weapon or object used. 

Closer examination of the injury will reveal that the outer table is driven into the diploe, and the inner table has irregular fractures or may be comminuted. 

The depth of the fracture varies according to the velocity with which the impact is delivered. When a hammer is used, the fracture is circular or in the shape of an arc of a circle. The diameter of the fracture is the same as the striking surface. There are generally no radiating linear fractures. 

Other options:

Option A - Comminuted fractures are caused by a greater intensity force striking over a broad area such as crushing head injuries, repeated blows by weapons with a large striking area, or falling from height. In a comminuted fracture, there will be two or more intersecting lines of fracture which divide the bone into three or more fragments. 

Option B - Pond fracture is also known as an indented fracture. This is a dent in the skull. They are caused by an obstetric forceps blade, a blow from a blunt object, etc. They occur only in the infant skulls.

Option C - Gutter fractures occur mainly in oblique bullet wounds as it removes a part of the thickness of the bone.

Related Pearl: Types of skull vault fracture

Diastatic fracture/ sutural fracture - It involves the separation of sutures due to blow with a blunt weapon or from cerebral edema.

Fissured fracture/ linear fracture:

  • They are breaks in the bone that traverse the full thickness of the skull from the outer to inner table.
  • They are usually fairly straight with no bone displacement.
  • The common cause of injury is blunt force trauma where the impact energy transferred over a wide area of the skull.

Pond fracture/ indented fracture - It occurs in children due to elasticity of bones. 

Depressed fracture/ signature fracture - It is caused by a heavy weapon with a small striking surface. Its shape indicates the type of weapon which is produced (signature fracture).

Comminuted fracture/ spider-web fracture - It has a stellate appearance where there is no displacement of the fracture.

Ring fracture - It is usually caused due to a fall from height landing on feet. These occur in the posterior fossa around the foramen magnum.

questions.text: A 40-year-old woman alleges that a man assaulted her the previous night, causing a wound over her forearm. According to her history, the wound should be about 12–14 hours old. If the history regarding the timing of the injury is accurate, you would expect the abrasion to appear as

choices.text: A fresh bright red lesion without any scab
A scab that is about to fall off

questions.solution:
An abrasion that was sustained 12 to 14 hours ago would show a bright red scab as lymph and blood dry up.

Abrasions are superficial wounds produced due to the destruction of the epidermis. Although the exact age of the wound cannot be determined, based on the healing and appearance of the wound, an estimated time can be given.

Abrasion types:

  • Linear abrasions (scratches): Caused by relative movement of a pointed object on the skin. It leaves a clean area at the start and tags at the end.
    • e.g. nail, thorn, or the point of a sword or knife.
  • Grazed abrasions (sliding /scrapping/grinding abrasion): Caused by relative movement of a rough surface on a wide area of skin.
    • known as brush burns.
    • e.g. fall, a victim being dragged on the ground, road traffic accidents.
  • Impact abrasions (imprint abrasions): Caused by the impact of a rigid hard rough surface over a localized area of the skin, without any movement
    • e.g. fingernails, tires, grills, bicycle chains, or bite marks.
  • Friction abrasions (pressure abrasion): Caused by pressure upon the skin with an agent with a smooth surface, accompanied by movement.
    • e.g. ligature marks around the neck in hanging, strangulation.
  • Patterned abrasion: Caused by impact abrasion or pressure abrasion, reproducing the pattern of the object causing it

Note: Grazed abrasion is the most common type of abrasion.

questions.text: A 53-year-old male patient who has worked in the mining and smelting industry for more than 15 years presented with pigmentation on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and the neck as in the given image. On further examination, a transverse white line was seen on his fingernails. What is your diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of chronic arsenic poisoning. We reach this diagnosis by considering the occupational history, raindrop pattern of skin pigmentation, and the Aldrich-Mees lines on the fingernails of the patient.

Arsenic poisoning

In its metallic form, arsenic is not poisonous, but when it unites with oxygen, it forms poisonous vapors of arsenic trioxide. These interfere with cellular respiration, damaging mitochondrial enzymes. It is present in fruit sprays, copper and gold mineral deposits, weed-killers, insecticides, rat poisons, wallpapers, and artificial flowers.

There are several types of arsenic poisoning:

  • Fulminant - When massive doses are rapidly absorbed, death occurs in 1–3 hours due to shock and peripheral vascular failure.
  • Gastrointestinal - This is the most common form of acute poisoning and resembles bacterial food poisoning. There is a constriction in the throat and difficulty in swallowing. The stools are dark-colored, stinking, and bloody initially and later take a colorless odorless watery form similar to the rice-water stools of cholera.
  • Chronic poisoning - It occurs due to repeated daily exposure. The main features include finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation that appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. In prolonged contact, hyperkeratosis of the palms and soles occurs along with the development of a transverse white line in the fingernails called the Aldrich-Mees lines.

Tests to detect arsenic poisoning:

  • 24-hour urinary excretion of arsenic
  • Detection of arsenic by atomic absorption spectroscopy
  • Marsh and Reinsch tests are now considered obsolete.

The preferred treatment option is freshly prepared hydrated ferric oxide, which converts toxic arsenic to non-toxic ferric arsenite. DMSA (Succimer), British anti-Lewisite (BAL), and penicillamine can also be used. 

Other options:

Option A - Phosphorus is an inorganic irritant poison that exists in two forms—highly toxic white phosphorus and non-toxic red phosphorus. The white form is used in fertilizers, insecticides, fireworks, etc., whereas the red form is seen on the sides of a matchbox.

Phosphorus poisoning presents with clinical features like severe abdominal pain, hepatomegaly, hematemesis, jaundice, and hemorrhages. In chronic poisoning, phossy jaw may occur. It is the osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw with multiple sinuses discharging foul-smelling pus.

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates making it harmless. Activated charcoal helps in the adsorption of the poison.

Option B - Acute copper poisoning is due to inhalation of a large amount of copper dust or fumes, which leads to upper respiratory tract irritation, conjunctivitis, and sinus irritation. Contact with the skin may lead to irritant contact dermatitis and a greenish-blue discoloration of the skin. 

In chronic poisoning, symptoms mostly resemble those of Wilson's disease, mainly including gradual anemia, peripheral neuritis, and muscle atrophy.

Option C - Acute mercury poisoning presents with corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea, which may progress to pulmonary edema and fibrosis. The symptom profile in children is similar to that of Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome).

Chronic exposure to elemental mercury leads to a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes. 

The characteristic Danbury tremors occur first in the hands and later progress to the lips and tongue, eventually involving the arms and legs. Over time, these become more severe, and the patient is unable to dress, walk properly, or write legibly. These are also known as hatter's shakes or glassblower's shakes. The most severe form is concussion mercurialis in which all activity is lost.

Acrodynia or pink disease - It is an idiosyncratic hypersensitivity reaction to chronic mercury exposure, seen particularly in children. The hands and feet become puffy, pinkish, painful, and paresthetic, with peeling of the skin.

questions.text: An 89-year-old woman was seen dead at home. Her bloodstained clothes were sent for examination to your forensic laboratory. On adding a reagent, feathery crystals of hemochromogen arranged in clusters appeared in 5 minutes.  What is the test done?
questions.solution:
The test done in the above scenario is the Takayama test.

The Takayama test or hemochromogen crystal test is a microchemical test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used is Takayama reagent. If bloodstain is present, pink feathery crystals of hemochromogen or reduced alkaline hematin appear in a few minutes. The test is negative if the crystals are not formed in 30 minutes. This test is more reliable and gives positive results with old stains.

Other options:

Option B: The Teichmann test or hemin crystal test is also a test used to detect bloodstains. The stain used glacial acetic acid and a small crystal of sodium chloride. If bloodstain is present, faint yellowish-red to brownish-black rhombic crystals of hemin or hematin chloride appear. When hydrogen peroxide is added, the hematin crystals give bubbles of gas.

Option C: The Barberio test is used to detect seminal fluid. When a saturated aqueous or alcoholic solution of picric acid is added to the spermatic fluid, yellow needle-shaped rhombic crystals of spermine picrate are produced.

Option D: The Florence test is used to detect the presence of semen. The stain used is 10% hydrochloric acid and Florence solution (potassium iodide, iodine, and water). If semen is present, dark brown rhombic or needle-shaped crystals of choline iodide appear immediately.

questions.text: Which of the following tubes is ideally used for performing gastric lavage in patients with suspected poisoning?
questions.solution:
The tube used for performing gastric lavage is the Ewald tube. It is also known as Boa tube, stomach tube, or orogastric lavage tube.

Gastric lavage is the administration and evacuation of small volumes of liquid through an orogastric tube to remove toxic substances within the stomach. In adults, small amounts of warm water or saline are administered and, via a siphoning action, removed again. In children, normal saline is used because children are at greater risk of developing hyponatremia if lavaged with water.

In an unconscious patient, gastric lavage is performed after induction of general anesthesia with the patient intubated, to prevent aspiration.

Ryle tube (nasogastric tube) is indicated in intestinal obstruction and nutritional support. It is also used for gastric lavage but is preferred more in children.

Sengstaken Blakemore tube is used for balloon tamponade in case of hemorrhage due to esophageal varices. 

Salem Sump tube is used for gastrointestinal decompression. It has 2 lumens.

questions.text: A 71-year-old woman is found in her bed with a scarf tied around her neck. Her face is cyanotic and congested with conjunctival petechiae. Removal of the scarf revealed a ligature mark on her neck. Which of the following is not a feature of antemortem ligature marks?

choices.text: The ligature mark reflects the ligature material used.
The ligature mark is usually below the laryngeal prominence.
The ligature mark does not have to go fully around the neck.
Vital reaction is present around the ligature mark.

questions.solution:
Option B is not a feature of antemortem ligature marks. Antemortem ligature marks are usually present above the laryngeal prominence. 

Ligature marks are seen in ligature strangulation or hanging. In strangulation, a constricting band is placed around the neck, which results in congestion, cyanosis, and petechiae. The ligature marks due to hanging have a suspension point, whereas those from manual strangulation do not. 

If the strangulation is homicidal in nature, there may also be scratches or bruises around the mark. They may be defensive wounds from the victim or previous attempts at manual strangulation. 

When pressure on the neck is applied, the following changes take place in any order, depending on the site of pressure and force used:  

  • Impaired venous return due to obstruction of jugular veins: This causes cyanosis, congestion, and petechiae.
  • Cerebral ischemia due to obstruction of the carotid arteries
  • Vagal inhibition of the heart due to stimulation of baroreceptor nerve endings in the carotid sinus
  • Closing the airway at the level of the pharynx due to elevation of the larynx and tongue

Other options: 

Option A - Ligature marks can reflect the ligature material. The mark is an important piece of evidence. It can tell us about the size and material even if the ligature has been removed from the scene.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy was brought to the OPD following a sting on his toe. On examination, he had tachycardia and hypertension and his pupils were dilated. Local examination of the wound showed mild erythema. The arachnid responsible for the sting is shown below. Which of the following drugs is used to counteract these effects?
questions.solution:
The clinical stem with the image showing a scorpion points to a scorpion bite, for which prazosin acts as a physiological antidote counteracting the symptoms of tachycardia, hypertension, and mydriasis. 

Most scorpion stings cause pain at the site of the bite. Systemic toxicity occurs in <10% of stings but is more commonly seen in infants and children. The venom is a clear, colorless toxalbumen and is generally classified as either hemolytic or neurotoxic. The venom is a potent autonomic stimulator resulting in the release of massive amounts of catecholamines from the adrenals. It also has a direct effect on the myocardium.

It can present as neurotoxicity with restlessness or seizure-like activity, abnormal oculomotor function, and loss of pharyngeal muscle control leading to respiratory compromise. Tongue fasciculations and hypersalivation are also common. Cardiovascular toxicity from systemic envenomation includes tachycardia, hypertension, pulmonary edema, and cardiogenic shock.

If the scorpion has hemolytic venom, the reaction is mainly local, with edema, pain, and reddening. This usually lasts for one to two hours. 

Treatment:

  • Pain- Paracetamol, NSAIDs, or opioids 
  • Sedation for agitation, oculomotor abnormalities, uncoordinated neuromuscular activity, muscle spasms- Benzodiazepines 
  • Hypertension and pulmonary edema- Prazosin counteracts the adrenergic surge that can lead to these effects
  • Cardiogenic shock- Antivenom, prazosin, nitroglycerin, dobutamine
  • Cholinergic effects- Atropine
  • Supportive care, wound care

questions.text: A person with suspected marijuana consumption is brought by the police for urine drug testing. He claims single use of marijuana at a party. Up to how many days can the drug be detected in his urine?
questions.solution:
After a single use of marijuana, tetrahydrocannabinol (active principle of Cannabis) can be detected in urine tests for up to 3 days.

Marijuana or Cannabis consists of the dried flowering tops and leaves of the plant Cannabis sativa. Hashish is prepared from the resin of the stems and leaves of this plant.

With long-term use, cannabinoids can be detected up to 30 days or longer after abstinence.

questions.text:
An unconscious man without any ID on him is brought to the casualty by bystanders after an RTA. His blood pressure is 80/60 mmHg. USG abdomen reveals a ruptured spleen. He is shifted for surgery without obtaining consent. What is the medico-legal justification for this course of action called?

ID - Identity document
RTA - Road traffic accident
questions.solution:
The medico-legal justification for this course of action is the doctrine of implied consent.

According to IPC section 92, if a patient is unconscious and there is an imminent danger to the life of the patient and there is no designated relative or the relative is unavailable, then consent is deemed to have been given. This is called the doctrine of implied consent. However, for this doctrine to be applicable, the patient must require emergency treatment to save life or limb. This doctrine is not applicable in a non-emergency or after the emergency has been handled adequately.

Other options:

Option A: Res ipsa loquitur means 'the thing speaks for itself'. It is used as supportive evidence of negligence on the part of the doctor. Say leaving behind a scalpel or scissors whilst operating leading to sepsis/peritonitis speaks for itself.

Option C: A competent person who is aware of being entitled to informed consent may give up the right to give consent, if he so wishes. This is called a therapeutic waiver.

Option D: If full disclosure is disadvantageous to the patient (e.g. in patients with anxiety), then the doctor can withhold certain information from the patient. However, he should disclose the full information to a competent relative of the patient. This is called therapeutic privilege.

questions.text: An autopsy of a police officer revealed a bullet in the parapharyngeal space. There is a small healed entry wound on the neck. The bullet is surrounded by fibrous tissue and there is no fresh bleeding around it. What is this bullet called?
questions.solution:
This bullet is called a souvenir bullet.

A souvenir bullet is one that has been lodged in the body for a long time with no fresh bleeding around it and is surrounded by a dense fibrous tissue capsule. They can be visualized on x-rays. They are usually a result of bullet lodging in an inaccessible space which may result in more damage on attempted retrieval. e.g. Bullet in the skull.

Other options - 

Option A - Dumdum bullets are bullets that fragment extensively when they hit an object.

Option B - Tracer bullets leave a visible trace while in flight which allows the gunner to observe its trajectory. A small portion in the rear of the bullet is devoid of the core. This space is filled with a flammable chemical compound that is red in color. Flash from the propellant ignites this mixture that causes the bullet to shed red sparks during flight.

The image shows tracer bullets:

 

Option D - Tandem bullet (Piggyback bullet) is when two bullets come out with a single shot. Seen with unused or locally made weapons. It occurs when the first bullet has been struck in the barrel, fails to leave, and gets ejected with subsequently fired bullet.

Related Pearl: Types of bullets:

1. Ricochet bullet: Bullet first strikes an intermediate object and then after being reflected strikes the target. It produces a key hole entry wound .

2. Yawning bullet: Travels in an irregular fashion.

3. Tandem (Piggy Back) Bullet Effect: Two bullets are ejected one after the other; first bullet failed to leave the barrel and is ejected by subsequently fired bullet. This occurs due to defect in the weapon or due to faulty ammunition or with loaded firearms unused for several years. Tandem cartridge (also called duplex cartridge) is a single cartridge containing two bullets. 

 

4. Frangible bullet: Fragments on hitting the target.

5. Dum Dum bullet: Tip is chiseled out, fragments extensively on impact.

6. Tumbling bullet:  Rotates end on end during its motion. This produces an atypical entry wound .  

7. Souvenir bullet:  Bullet left in the body for a long time and covered with dense fibrous connective tissue.

8. Tracer bullet: This type of bullet leaves a visible mark or trace while in flight so that the gunner can observe the strike of shot. Rear portion of bullet is filled with mixture of barium nitrate, strontium nitrate and powdered magnesium which is ignited by the burning powder. Mixture burns and sheds red sparks which makes the projectile visible to naked eye which enables shooter to make aiming corrections.

9. Incendiary bullet: It is filled with white phosphorous and ignites the target.

questions.text: Which of the following statements does not apply to cross-examination in a court of law?

choices.text: Witness is examined by the defense lawyer
Objective of cross-examination is to weaken case of opponent
There is no time limit to cross examination

questions.solution:
Leading questions are allowed in a cross-examination according to Sec. 143 IEA. However, they are not allowed during the direct examination conducted by the summoning counsel.

In the event that Judge is satisfied that the witness is hostile, leading questions may be allowed during direct examination. 

Leading questions (Sec. 141 IEA) are defined as questions that suggest an answer that is favorable for the case of the summoning counsel or in alignment with their claim. 

Other options:

Options 1, 3, 4 - In cross-examination, the witness is examined by the defense lawyer or adverse party with an objective to elicit favorable facts to their case, to test the accuracy of the witness statements, to unearth new or old facts, and also, to discredit the witness. 

While leading questions are allowed in cross-examination, the Judge can disallow questions that are indecent (Sec. 151 IEA) or questions asked with an intention to insult or offend the witness in any form (Sec. 152 IEA).

There is no time limit to the duration of cross-examination. 

 

The sequence of examination in the recording of evidence is as follows -

Sequence of Examination Objective
  • Examination-in-Chief/ Direct examination by the party that summoned the witness

To elicit the facts of the case from the witness. Leading questions are not allowed.
  • Cross-examination by the defense lawyer
 To elicit facts favorable to their case and test the reliability of the witness. Leading questions are allowed.
  • Re-examination by the party that summoned the witness
 To resolve doubts that formed during cross-examination and re-emphasize the party's perspective.

questions.text: A child who has been saved from a human trafficking ring has been subjected to a medical examination. The child has no recollection of his identity. His age is estimated to be around 14 years. Which of the following bones from this x-ray help in confirmation of this child's age?
questions.solution:
From the given x-ray, the first metacarpal and pisiform help in confirming this child's age. The child's age is estimated to be between 12 to 17 years. 

In the x-ray photograph of the wrist and hand, the lower epiphyses of the first metacarpals are not united with the shaft. The epiphyses of the metacarpal bones fuse with the shaft between the age of 15 to 17 years. The pisiform has ossified. This makes the minimum age of the child to be 12 years. Hence, the child's age will be between 12 and 17 years.

Hence, the pisiform and metacarpals help in estimating the age of the child in this case. 

Ossification centres of carpal bones:

  • Capitate: 1–3 months
  • Hamate:  2–4 months
  • Triquetral: 2–3 years
  • Lunate: 3–4 years
  • Scaphoid: 4–6 years
  • Trapezium: 5-6 years
  • Trapezoid: 5–6 years
  • Pisiform: 10–12 years

The lower end of the radius appears at 2 years of age and fuses at 18–19 years of age. The lower end of the ulna appears at 5–6 years of age and fuses at 17–18 years of age. Here, both remain unfused indicating further that the age is likely to be less than 18 years.

questions.text: What weather is favorable for mummification?
questions.solution:
The absence of moisture in the air and the continuous action of dry or warmed air are necessary for the process of mummification.

Mummification is the process of dehydration or drying and shriveling of the cadaver that occurs from the evaporation of water. The natural appearances of the body and general facial features are preserved.

questions.text: A young man deliberately ingested a poisonous liquid in an attempt to commit suicide. The bottle from which he ingested the liquid is shown below. Emergency management was done as soon as he was taken to the hospital. When examining the urobag a few hours later, what color will you expect the urine to be?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario is suggestive of carbolic acid/phenol poisoning.  A few hours later, the urine in the urobag will be expected to have a smoky green or olive green color. This urine color change occurs due to the oxidation of the metabolic products of phenol—hydroquinone and pyrocatechol.

Carbolic acid or phenol is an organic acid that is used as a disinfectant and solvent. It has a characteristic phenolic odor. Poisoning by carbolic acid is called carbolism.

On exposure to the skin, carbolic acid coagulates the proteins and causes the formation of an eschar that will come off as slough later. It can damage the nerves and cause tingling and numbness.

On ingestion, a burning sensation may be felt, along with nausea and vomiting. Vomiting puts the patient at risk of aspiration pneumonia. The acid can also cause pulmonary and laryngeal edema, leading to difficulty breathing, and ultimately respiratory failure. Systemic features include headache, dizziness, syncope, and even coma.

Diagnosis of carbolic acid poisoning can be made by adding a few drops of 10% ferric chloride to the patient's urine sample. If the sample turns violet or blue, it indicates the presence of phenolic compounds. The urine sample would also reduce Benedict's and Fehling's solutions.

Treatment involves removing contaminated clothing and washing the skin. If the patient has ingested the poison, cautious gastric lavage with 20% alcohol, glycerol, or vegetable oil should be carried out. MgSO4 or liquid paraffin should be left in the stomach to remove surface phenol and prevent deep penetration. Parenteral saline can also be administered to correct the circulatory depression, dilute the carbolic acid content of the blood, and promote its excretion. Hemodialysis can be carried out if there is renal failure.

Post mortem, the viscera should be preserved in a saturated salt solution. The skin has a reddish appearance with necrosis or ulceration. The body has a characteristic phenolic odor. The esophagus may look reddish and like parchment. The internal surface of the stomach may show prominent rugae with a leathery appearance, due to the opaque, coagulated, grey, or brown mucosa.

Other options-

Option (B): Pale yellow is the color of normal urine, so this is not the correct answer.

Option (C & D): Orange-red color of urine can be seen in patients on rifampicin therapy.

questions.text: During your rotation in the forensic medicine and toxicology department, you notice the specimen of a fetus with a  length of 16 cm. What is the age of the fetus likely to be?
questions.solution:
The age of the fetus in months, calculated using the Rule of Haase, is √16 = 4 months. 

Rule of Haase enables the estimation of the age of the fetus in months from its crown-heel length (in cm) in the first 5 months. It is a rough method of calculating the age of the fetus. During the first five months of pregnancy, the square root of the length gives the approximate age of the fetus in months.

Haase's Modification of Morisson's Law:

During the last five months, the length of the fetus (in cm) divided by five gives the age in months.

Example - A fetus of length 40cm is likely to be 8 months old.

questions.text: Pearson formula is used to estimate
questions.solution:
Pearson formula is used for the estimation of stature.

This mathematical formula can be used to estimate the length of the long bones to identify the stature of the individual from the skeletal remains that are incomplete or severely disintegrated. It uses different calculating factors for bones from males and females based on whether the bones are wet (intact cartilage) or dried (devoid of cartilage). This method was used for a long time in European subjects.

For each long bone, there is a separate multiplying factor and a constant factor. The constant factor is added to the product of the length of the long bone and multiplying factor. The addition of certain values for the soft parts is also done. 

Other formulas for stature estimation: 

  • Trotter and Gleser formula
  • Dupertuis and Hadden formula
  • Steele formula

questions.text: A man who was working at a construction site suddenly collapsed on a hot summer afternoon. Bystanders reported that there was no sweating despite the hot weather. On examination, his pupils were constricted and the skin was dry, hot, and flushed. The physician found that the rectal temperature was 42ºC.  What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The most likely diagnosis in this patient is heat stroke.

The given clinical scenario of the patient collapsing suddenly on a hot summer afternoon while working, with no signs of sweating, constricted pupils, and a rectal temperature of 42ºC, is highly suggestive of heat stroke.

Heat stroke/thermic fever/heat hyperpyrexia is a condition characterized by a raised rectal temperature of >41°C associated with psychosis, stupor, coma, and convulsions. It is caused by failure of cutaneous circulation and sweating that leads to the failure of the heat regulation center of the hypothalamus. The predisposing factors include high temperature, increased humidity, minor infections, old age, lack of acclimatization, and alcoholism.

Heat stroke types:

  • Exertion-induced heat stroke is seen in people with prolonged exposure to or physical exertion in high temperatures, usually without adequate training.
  • Sedentary heatstroke is a disease of elderly or infirm people whose cardiovascular systems are unable to adapt to the stress of a hot environment and release sufficient heat such that body temperature rises.

There is a sudden onset of symptoms with a sudden collapse accompanied by unconsciousness. Typical vital sign abnormalities include tachypnea, tachycardia, and hypotension. The skin is dry, hot, and flushed with no signs of sweating. The pupils are constricted. Other specific signs include rapid Kussmaul type of breathing, delirium, coma, and convulsions. 

Although there is no single specific diagnostic test, clinical features of exposure to heat stress, CNS dysfunction, and core temperature of >41°C help establish the preliminary diagnosis.

Autopsy findings include the presence of edema and reduction of Purkinje's cells in the cerebellum.

Other options:

Option A - Heat cramps are seen in people working at high temperatures with profuse sweating. It is due to rapid dehydration of the body by the loss of water and electrolytes in the sweat. It has a sudden onset associated with sudden, painful paroxysmal cramps in the muscles of the arms, legs, and abdomen. The pupils are dilated with facial flushing.

Options C and D - Both heat syncope and heat prostration are conditions resulting from increased exposure to heat without a raise in the body temperature. They are precipitated by increased muscular work and unsuitable clothing. The clinical signs include cold skin, subnormal temperature, dilated pupils, pale face, thready pulse, and loss of consciousness (in heat syncope).

questions.text:
Identify the medical presentations associated with the deliriant poison derived from the plant given below.
  1. Magnan syndrome
  2. Amotivational syndrome
  3. Run amok
  4. Nasal septum ulceration
  5. Loss of self-respect
questions.solution:
The given plant is Erythroxylum coca. Cocaine is the principal alkaloid found in the cultivated varieties of coca. The correct answer is 1, 4, and 5 only.

Cocaine is a CNS stimulant. CNS stimulation (anxiety, hyperactivity), CVS overactivity (tachycardia, hypertension), and increased respiratory rate are seen in poisoning with cocaine causing sympathetic toxidrome.

The water-soluble form (-hydrochloride) can be injected or snorted. Tattoos may be made to cover the injection marks. Whilst another form (-sulfate) can be smoked. It gives a cracking sound when burnt. It inhibits the uptake of dopamine, norepinephrine, and serotonin. It thus, enhances the action of these neurotransmitters.

It causes digestive disturbances, anorexia, salivation, tachycardia, tachypnoea, and insomnia. The face is pale, eyes sunken, pupils dilated, and the gaze is shifty. 
 
Magnan's syndrome or cocaine bugs is a characteristic feature in which there is a feeling as if grains of sand are under the skin or as if small insects are creeping on the skin, giving rise to an itching sensation (formication, tactile hallucination) and resultant excoriation, which leads to irregular scratches and ulcers.
 
It is a drug of addiction and causes a lowering of moral tone and loss of decency and self-respect. Sniffing habits leads to nasal septum ulceration.

Initial management involves the administration of activated charcoal and gastric lavage if it has been ingested.

Treatment involves the administration of benzodiazepines to control heart rate/ seizures, propranolol to control cardiac arrhythmia, and haloperidol to treat psychosis. Counseling needs to be done to avoid resisting the urge for repetitive usage.

  • Run-amok - Run-amok is a psychic disturbance resulting from the continued use or sudden consumption of Cannabis and is characterized by a peculiar homicidal mania. The person is not held responsible for his acts since ‘run amok’ is considered a disorder of mind and not intoxication.

questions.text:
A child is brought to the OPD with a history of repeated injuries that seem to be non-accidental. A diagnosis of battered baby syndrome is suspected. Which of the following clinical features are characteristic of the condition?
  1. Subdural hemorrhage
  2. Laceration over forehead
  3. "String of beads" appearance on chest x-ray
  4. Bucket-handle fracture
  5. Bruise over knee
questions.solution:
Statements 1, 3, and 4 are characteristic features of battered baby syndrome.

The battered baby syndrome refers to a constellation of clinical findings suggestive of repetitive physical abuse in a child via non-accidental violence by a parent or a guardian. Additionally, there may be associated deprivation of nutrition, care, and affection. It is usually seen in children less than 3 years of age with a history of emotional or financial problems in the family.

Clinical features:

  • Injuries of different ages and in different stages of healing
  • Bruises may be seen on either side of the chest, behind the axillae, and down the anterior chest wall indicative of the hand impressions of the perpetrator.
  • Violent shaking of a child leads to infantile whiplash syndrome. Repetitive and vigorous shaking of an infant gives rise to a triad of clinical findings—encephalopathy, retinal bleeds, and subdural hemorrhage. 
  • Multiple deformities of the long bones and ribs. Some characteristic fractures include the following:
    • Knob fractures are a result of callus formation in healing ribs that have been damaged due to squeezing. Chest x-ray shows a "string of beads" appearance in the paravertebral gutter.
    • Bucket-handle fractures are typical corner fractures near the metaphyseal regions of the long bones in the arms and legs.

Other statements:

Forehead lacerations, knee bruises, and injuries on bony prominences are non-specific features that may be due to age-appropriate falls. They are usually accidental and not characteristic of the condition.

questions.text: You are examining a 22-year-old college student whose oral cavity appears as below. You would suspect drug abuse and order a 'tox screen' for which of the following substances?
questions.solution:
The image shows a case of suspected meth mouth with a close-up shot of the lower right posterior teeth. Meth mouth is advanced tooth decay which is common in habitual methamphetamine users.

Methamphetamine is also colloquially referred to as 'ice', 'crystal', 'chalk', and 'meth'. It used to be known as 'speed' or 'go'. It can be taken by ingestion, intravenous injection, inhalation, or nasal insufflation. It enhances the release and inhibits the reuptake of catecholamines at the presynaptic terminals.

Advanced tooth decay or meth mouth is commonly seen in habitual meth abusers. It may be multifactorial and due to poor oral hygiene, dry mouth, consumption of high-carbohydrate carbonated beverages, jaw clenching, and tooth grinding.

Amphetamine intoxication is suspected in cases presenting with agitation, mydriasis, diaphoresis, tachycardia, tachypnea, hypertension, and hyperthermia, similar to cocaine intoxication. Mental status may be normal or severely agitated and paranoid.

Other options:

Option A: Chronic use of LSD (lysergic acid diethylamide) can cause a flashback phenomenon. When the person re-lives the experience under the influence of a substance periodically in the absence of drug intake for months or years it is known as the flashback phenomenon.

Option B: Phencyclidine is taken orally, smoked, injected, or inhaled. It may lead to acute psychosis and violence.

questions.text: During the examination of a victim of assault, you notice a wound with ragged, irregular, and uneven margins with tears diverging at an angle from the end of the main wound. The wound shows typical ‘swallow tails’. Bleeding from this wound is not significant and a closer examination shows crushed blood vessels and hair bulbs. You would document this wound as:
questions.solution:
The characteristics described are consistent with that of a lacerated wound.

In a lacerated wound, the margins are ragged, irregular, and uneven. Tearing at the ends of a laceration, at angles diverging from the main one itself are called swallow tails.

The edges of the laceration may indicate the direction in which the blow or force was applied. The depth of the wound shows bridges of irregularly torn fibrous tissue, blood vessels, and nerves and can be soiled by mud, sand, glass, brick particles, vegetation, machine oils, hair, or fibres. These materials embedded in the wound are of great medicolegal value.

Lacerated wounds do not bleed much as the vessels are crushed and torn, thus facilitating hemostasis. The exception to this is injuries to the scalp, where temporal arteries may bleed freely as they are firmly bound and unable to contract. Lacerations over the hairy areas will show hair bulbs crushed and buried into the depth of the wound. Because of the crushing and tearing nature of the production of lacerations, there can be associated abrasion or bruising.

Swallow tail in a lacerated wound is shown in the image below:

Other options:

Option A- An incised wound is a clean-cut wound made with a sharp-edged instrument through the skin and subcutaneous tissues, including blood vessels. The length of the wound is more than the depth and width. The edges are well-defined and usually everted, free from contusions and abrasions. It is usually spindle-shaped. The depth is higher at the commencement and progressively becomes shallower, known as tailing. Tailing determines the direction of the force applied when creating the wound.

Option B- Chop wounds or slash wounds are the wounds produced by chopping motion, made with heavy and sharp weapons like axe, cleave, etc. The dimensions of the wound correspond to the crosssection of the penetrating part of the weapon. The margins are sharp and show slight abrasion and bruising with the destruction of underlying organs. The presence of an incised wound on the skin with an underlying fracture or deep grove in the bone indicates a chop wound.

The image below shows a chop wound.

Option C- A stab wound is a type of mechanical injury that is produced when force is applied along the long axis of a narrow, pointed object like a knife, sword, chisel, needle, screwdriver, etc, into the depth of the body. 

The margins of the wound are clean-cut and inverted. The length of the wound is slightly less than the width of the weapon. The width of the wound corresponds to the maximum possible width of the blade. The depth of the wound is greater than the length and width of the external injury on the skin surface. The shape of the surface wound depends on the type of weapon, cutting surface, the direction of thrust, cleavage lines, etc. The shape of the wound is usually triangular or wedge-shaped. Depending on the type of instrument used, one side of the wound may be sharp, while another side may be blunt. The blunt side may show small splits at each corner, called fishtailing.

Postmortem hypostasis/Postmortem staining/Postmortem lividity/Livor mortis/Suggilation refers to bluish-purple or reddish-purple discoloration of the superficial layers of the skin due to the collection of blood in toneless capillaries. 

It is an early postmortem change that occurs due to engorged vessels showing through the skin seen on the dependent parts due to the pooling of blood under the effect of gravity. 

This staining starts as mottled patches 1-3 hours following death and develops to a uniform area of staining in 3-6 hours. Full development and fixation of hypostasis occur within 6-12 hours. This finding usually develops within 4 hours and persists until putrefaction. Fixation of hypostasis occurs earlier in summer. It is delayed in asphyxial deaths and in intracranial lesions.

questions.text: An 8-year-old girl is brought for medical examination by her parents, with complaints of being sexually assaulted by her neighbor. What would be the likely hymenal finding in this child?

choices.text: Ruptured since it is superficially situated
Ruptured since it is very thin
Unruptured since it is deeply situated
Unruptured since it is highly elastic

questions.solution:
In this child, the hymen is likely to be unruptured since it is deeply situated and usually intact after intercourse.

 As the vagina is very small, it is impossible for the penetration of the adult organ to take place. In children, there are few or no signs of general   violence, as the child is unaware of the assault and incapable of resisting.

 The penis is usually placed within the vulva and between the thighs. Forceful penetration may cause the penis to be pushed backward by the   symphysis pubis, and the hymen may be torn posteriorly.

 A few indicators for routine enquiry are pain on urination and/or defecation, abdominal pain, inability to sleep, sudden withdrawal from peers/adults,   feelings of anxiety, nervousness, helplessness, weight loss, and feelings of ending one’s life.

 On examination, blood may be oozing from the injured parts or blood clots may be found. An attempt to separate the thighs may cause pain. The child    may walk with difficulty due to the pain. The labia majora may be contused, abraded, or lacerated. Circumferential tears may be seen in children        up  to six years.

questions.text: A 50-year-old male patient who has worked in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years presents with swelling in the lower jaw. On further examination, multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus were noted. Which of the following chemicals is responsible for this?
questions.solution:
The clinical scenario of a male patient working in the gunpowder and explosive manufacturing industry for more than 20 years, presenting with swelling in the lower jaw and multiple discharging sinuses with foul-smelling pus is suggestive of a phossy jaw, seen in chronic phosphorus poisoning.

Phosphorus is a non-metallic, inorganic irritant poison that affects cellular oxidation. It exists in two forms, white phosphorus, a highly toxic form, and red phosphorus, the non-toxic form. 

Chronic phosphorus poisoning is common among the workers of phosphorus industries, who have had chronic exposure to phosphorus fumes over a period of years. It causes necrosis of the lower jaw in the region of a decayed tooth.

Patients initially present with toothache, followed by swelling of the jaw, loosening of the teeth, necrosis of gums, and sequestration of the bone in the mandible producing considerable facial disfigurement. Phossy jaw is the osteomyelitis and necrosis of the jaw, with foul-smelling pus discharging multiple sinuses. It is managed surgically and by prevention of further absorption of the poison. 

Gastric lavage with potassium permanganate oxidizes phosphorus into phosphoric acid and phosphates. Activated charcoal can be used to adsorb the poison. 

Other options:

Option A - Acute arsenic poisoning resembles bacterial food poisoning. Initially, they have dark-coloured, foul-smelling bloody stools, which later become colourless, odourless, and watery, resembling watery stools of cholera. 

Chronic arsenic poisoning occurs due to accidental ingestion of multiple small doses in food or drinks. In chronic poisoning, finely mottled, raindrop pigmentation appears on the skin of flexures, temples, eyelids, and neck. The rashes resemble fading measles rash. In prolonged poisoning, a transverse white line, called the Aldrich-Mees line, appears in fingernails. 


Option B: Prolonged ingestion of fluorides results in the mottling of teeth, an increase in the density of bones, lipping of bony margins of vertebrae, which sometimes produce pressure on the spinal cord leading to paraplegia.

Option C: Acute mercury poisoning occurs when elemental mercury vapors produce corrosive bronchitis with fever, chills, and dyspnea. In children, manifestations similar to Kawasaki disease (mucocutaneous lymph node syndrome) can be seen. Severe infection can cause loosening of teeth and necrosis of the jaw.

Chronic elemental mercury exposure yields a classic triad of gingivitis, tremors, and neuropsychiatric changes.

questions.text: A patient presents to the ER with irrelevant slurred speech. On examination, a dry mouth, dry and hot skin, and dilated pupils are noted. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
The given clinical scenario is suggestive of Datura poisoning.

The two species are jimson weed (Datura stramonium) and angel’s trumpet (Datura candida).

Seeds or other parts of the plant can be ingested or smoked. Poisoning leads to delirium, hallucinations, and seizures. Additionally, other classic anticholinergic effects, such as mydriasis, tachycardia, dry mouth and skin, blurred vision, urinary retention, and hyperthermia may present.

Gastric emptying is often delayed, and the small, plentiful seeds can become trapped among the gastrointestinal folds after ingestion. Thus gastric decontamination can be an important therapy.

Physostigmine, a reversible acetylcholine esterase antagonist, is an effective treatment for severe anticholinergic poisoning.

In India, the root and leaves of Jimsonweed (Datura) were burned and the smoke was inhaled to treat asthma. Around the 1800s, British colonists observed this and introduced the belladonna alkaloids in western medicine for the management of asthma.

questions.text: The body of a woman found in a water body was brought for autopsy. There is frothing at the mouth, the hand is clenched with soil and weeds, and bloodstained froth is present in the lungs. The Gettler test reveals that the chloride content is 30 mg% lower on the left side of the heart compared to the right. With the above case scenario, which option best describes the drowning?
questions.solution:
The above case scenario shows the features of antemortem drowning in freshwater.

Frothing and cadaveric spasm are suggestive of antemortem drowning. The Gettler test findings are consistent with freshwater drowning.

Gettler test - Normally, the chloride content is 600 mg% on either side of the heart. A difference of more than 25 mg% between the right and the left sides is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.

Freshwater drowning - The chloride content is lower on the left side of the heart due to dilution by freshwater.

Saltwater drowning- The chloride content is higher on the left side of the heart due to the entry of saltwater and hemoconcentration.

Given below are the features of antemortem drowning.

  • Froth - The presence of copious amounts of fine, shaving-lather-like froth at the mouth and the nostrils is the most characteristic finding of antemortem drowning. It is caused by the vigorous agitation of the tracheal and bronchial mucous secretions, edema fluid, and alveolar surfactant during respiratory efforts. 
  • Cutis anserina - The contraction of the erector pilorum muscles causes puckering and grainy appearance of the skin. This resembles goose skin; hence, it is called cutis anserina.
  • Washerwoman’s hand - Maceration of the skin on the palms and soles gives a wrinkled, sodden, and bleached appearance due to submersion.
  • Cadaveric spasm - Gravel, weed, soil, grass, etc. is firmly held in the clenched hands due to cadaveric spasm. This is a vital sign of antemortem drowning. The material also indicates the place of submersion.
  • Rigor mortis - This appears early in cases of a violent antemortem struggle.
  • Face - It is bloated and discolored, with cyanosis.
  • Eyes - Conjunctiva are suffused and pupils dilated.
  • Tongue - It may be swollen and protruded.
  • Antemortem injuries - These may be sustained by striking objects, such as rocks, during the fall into the water body. Examination for such injuries must be performed only after the body is dry.

Internal findings:

  • Lungs - They appear voluminous and distended show ballooning. The cut section will exude copious amounts of frothy, bloodstained fluid.
  • Larynx, trachea, and bronchioles - The presence of sand, silt, and aquatic vegetation in the trachea and lower respiratory tract are characteristic findings of antemortem drowning.
  • Heart and blood vessels- Gettler test can be done to estimate the chloride content in the right and left sides of the heart to differentiate between freshwater and saltwater drowning. 
  • Diatom test- Diatoms are microscopic algae. Their presence in the organs, particularly in the bone marrow, is suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Stomach and small intestines- These organs may contain water in some cases. Water present in the small intestine is positive evidence of death by drowning.
  • Middle ear - The presence of water in the middle ear is highly suggestive of antemortem drowning.
  • Brain - It is congested, and edematous, with loss of gray-white junction.


Options A, C, and D are not correct as the case does not show the findings of postmortem or saltwater drowning.

questions.text: A middle-aged male patient developed severe abdominal pain, vertigo, and convulsions after the consumption of the seeds shown in the image. Which of the following is the toxin present in this seed?
questions.solution:
The seeds shown in the image are those of the Abrus precatorius plant. Abrin is one of the toxic principles of this plant.

Toxic principles of Abrus precatorius:

  • Abrin (a toxalbumen)
  • Abrine (an amino acid)
  • Abralin (a glucoside)

Abrin acts by inhibiting protein synthesis, thereby resulting in cell death. The clinical features after oral ingestion of these seeds include abdominal pain, nausea, vomiting, bloody diarrhea, weakness, cold perspiration, trembling, weak rapid pulse, and miosis. Faintness, vertigo, dyspnea, and convulsions can also occur. If taken by injection, painful swelling, ecchymosis with inflammation, and necrosis are seen at the site of injection.

Medicolegal Importance:

  • It is commonly used as cattle poison in Indian villages by injecting the seed extract into the animal in the form of certain fine needle-shaped structures known as sui (meaning needle in Hindi).
  • These are prepared by mixing the seed extract with opium, datura, and spirit/water and then blended into a paste, shaped into fine needles and dried in the sun, and used to kill cattle by driving it deep into the animal body by blowing through a hollow bamboo pipe.

Other options:

Option A: Ricin is the toxic principle of the Ricinus communis plant. It causes the burning of oral mucosa similar to alkali burn, severe abdominal pain, hemolysis, convulsions, uremia, collapse, and death.

Option B- Crotin is the toxic principle of Croton tiglium. They present with hot burning pain from mouth to stomach, salivation, purging, vertigo, prostration, collapse, and death.
